problem.b: Two balls attached by a rod
problem.p: Let's consider a rigid object consisting of two small balls of masses m1 and m2 (m1 < m2) connected by a rod of length 2R and negligible mass. The object is placed on a horizontal and frictionless table contained in the x-y plane. The object is set to rotate counterclockwise as viewed from above the x-y plane with an angular speed ω. The axis of rotation passes through the center of the rod, point Q in the left figure. The point S in the right figure is located in the axis of rotation at a distance d below the point Q.

td.b: 1. The angular momentum about point Q
2. The angular momentum about point S

tr.td:
For each particle, the direction of the angular momentum about point Q is best represented by the arrow
Consider the balls' position vectors measured from point Q to be \(\vec{r}_1\) and \(\vec{r}_2\), and the balls' velocity vectors to be \(\vec{v}_1\) and \(\vec{v}_2\) as shown in the figure:
Following the right hand rule, the direction of the angular momentum of each particle is along the +z axis. Adding both vectors, the total angular momentum about point Q is also along the +z axis parallel to ω.

For each particle, the direction of the angular momentum about point S is best represented by the arrow
Consider the balls' position vectors measured from point S to be \(\vec{r}_1\) and \(\vec{r}_2\), and the balls' velocity vectors to be \(\vec{v}_1\) and \(\vec{v}_2\) as shown in the figure:
The angular momentum of each particle is perpendicular to the position and velocity vectors. Following the right hand rule, the angular momentum about point S of particle 1 is best represented by arrow 8 and the one of particle 2 by arrow 2 as shown below. As a result, the angular momentum vectors about point S are at an angle with respect to the angular velocity vector (+z axis).
